Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Evolutionary Mechanisms for Recruiting Promiscuous Enzyme Activities into New Metabolic Pathways

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The scientific goal of this project is to discover how and why certain enzymes are capable of evolving new functions. Previous research partially answered the "how" question: in addition to their biological function, many enzymes carry out "promiscuous" side reactions by chance. If a promiscuous activity becomes useful for an organism, natural selection will act to improve that activity. Although many enzymes have promiscuous activities, they might not be equally capable of evolving new functions. In order to identify characteristics that promote evolvability, this research project is comparing the evolution, structure, and function of a family of promiscuous enzymes to their non-promiscuous relatives. Identifying the sequence, structural, and catalytic properties that were required for the evolution of a new function will facilitate the development of new strategies for engineering other enzymes to carry out new activities. Improving protein engineering methodology has numerous applications in industry and medicine, such as using biodegradable enzymes to replace toxic chemicals in industrial processes.

Broader Impacts

This project will support education in the research laboratory and classroom, providing interdisciplinary training in bioinformatics and biochemistry, a major growth area in the biological sciences because of the development of high-throughput DNA sequencing technologies. The participation of under-represented minorities in scientific research will be increased by providing full-time summer internships to undergraduates recruited from colleges that mainly serve minority populations and have limited research opportunities. Active learning will be fostered through the augmentation of a lecture course with a research project that integrates concepts from metabolism with bioinformatics methods developed in the research laboratory. Finally, evolutionary thinking will be introduced into a freshman biochemistry and genetics class, with the goal that these students will become citizens who can explain the mechanisms of evolution and how it impacts their lives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On his chalkboard, physicist Richard Feynman wrote "What I cannot create, I do not understand". As of today, we cannot create enzymes that efficiently carry out every desired task. And we would like to: designer enzymes, which work in water, could replace many toxic processes that make pharmaceuticals and industrial chemicals used in everyday life. Enzymes are the catalysts that carry out most of the chemical reactions in cells. As chemical catalysts, their functions are ruled by the laws of chemistry and physics. But enzymes are made by living organisms, so the construction of enzymes is governed by evolution. Discovering how to design enzymes thus lies at the interface of evolution, chemistry, and physics. The goal of this project was to identify chemical and physical properties of catalytically promiscuous enzymes that enabled them to evolve new functions. Catalytic promiscuity is the ability of enzymes to carry out more than one chemical reaction. Most enzymes in cells have a single, primary reaction, but because enzymes carry out their reactions in a cleft filled with chemically reactive groups, any molecule that finds its way into the cleft could be chemically modified. If the modified molecule helps the cell grow and divide, then evolutionary changes that improve the enzyme?s ability to make the modified molecule could give the cell a growth advantage. Catalytic promiscuity is thus a toolbox of evolutionary possibilities.

At the beginning of this project, the recruitment and evolutionary improvement of a promiscuous activity to become a new, useful biological function was poorly documented in nature. The Glasner lab combined bioinformatics with biochemistry to determine when and how a certain promiscuous activity became a new biological function. We discovered that this new activity arose early in the evolution of the enzyme family, but remained a promiscuous (and biologically useless) activity for quite a long time. We could determine when the promiscuous activity became a biological function by determining what genes reside near the gene encoding the promiscuous enzyme. In bacteria, genes that encode enzymes which are involved in the same chemical process are often grouped together in the genome, so that they can be activated together. Species that only needed the original activity kept the gene that encoded the promiscuous enzyme next to one set of genes in the genome, but in other species, the gene occurred near a different set of genes whose encoded enzymes could work together in a new process that needed the promiscuous activity. This promiscuous enzyme was not encoded near the same genes in every genome, but with different sets of genes in different genomes. This indicates that several new processes that use the promiscuous enzyme evolved, emphasizing the concept that evolution is not a low-probability process that occurred long ago, but a continuous process that shapes living organisms today. Biochemical experiments identified two particularly important mutations in the gene encoding the promiscuous enzyme that increased the rate of the promiscuous activity, which made it more useful to the species that gained the gene. These experiments thus definitively demonstrated the recruitment of a nonbiological, promiscuous enzyme activity to become a new and useful biological activity.

This knowledge can be applied two ways. First, the useful mutations in the enzyme occur in many related genes, enabling us to predict that enzymes with the same mutations have the same function. This knowledge increases what we understand about the metabolic capabilities of microorganisms, which can potentially be harnessed for biomedical or industrial purposes. Second, the changes we identified improved the rate of the reaction, rather than how tightly the enzyme binds its substrate. Incorporating this knowledge into enzyme engineering methods would be valuable, because it has been much easier to design enzymes that bind tightly to molecules than to design enzymes that are fast catalysts.

This project also integrated research at the interface of bioinformatics and biochemistry into undergraduate and graduate education. Twenty undergraduates, fifteen graduate students, and one postdoc engaged in research for a few weeks to a few years during the project. They benefited by honing their scientific reasoning and laboratory skills, preparing them for graduate school, medical school, and research careers. Concepts about evolution were incorporated into two undergraduate biochemistry courses. Exposing students to evolutionary thinking throughout their undergraduate careers produces citizens who can explain how the process of evolution impacts cancer, antibiotic resistance, and complex genetic diseases that many of them will face as medical professionals and scientists.
